com.lonepulse.robozombie.processor
Class AbstractProcessorChain<LINK_RESULT,LINK_FAILURE extends Throwable>

java.lang.Object
  com.lonepulse.robozombie.processor.AbstractProcessorChain<LINK_RESULT,LINK_FAILURE>
All Implemented Interfaces:
Processor<LINK_RESULT,LINK_FAILURE>
Direct Known Subclasses:
RequestProcessorChain, ResponseProcessorChain
public abstract class AbstractProcessorChain<LINK_RESULT,LINK_FAILURE extends Throwable>
extends Object
implements Processor<LINK_RESULT,LINK_FAILURE>

This contract defines the services for a chain of sequentially executed ProcessorChainLinks. Each link in the chain may define aa successor ProcessorChainLink. If no successor is defined it signifies the end of the chain.

The terminal results of the processor chain will be the results produced by the final link in the chain. However, note that a Processor may choose not to process the input based on the targeting criteria specified in its implementation.

The execution of each ProcessorChainLink can be categorized as a traversal or a termination.

  1. Traversal: the execution of the current link followed by a progression to the next link. (see onTraverse(Object, ProcessorChainLink, Object...))
  2. Termination: the execution of the last link and subsequent return of the final result. (see onTerminate(Object, Object...))

Both of these services defer to the better judgment of the processor chain creator.

Since:
1.3.0

Version:
1.1.0

Author:
Lahiru Sahan Jayasinghe

Instantiates a new AbstractProcessorChain with the given ProcessorChainLink which will be assigned as the root link.

Method Detail

run

public LINK_RESULT run(Object... args)

Directs processing along the chain by executing the root ProcessorChainLink and delegating all successors to onTraverse(Object, ProcessorChainLink, Object...) and the terminal link to onTerminate(Object, Object...).

Specified by:
run in interface Processor<LINK_RESULT,LINK_FAILURE extends Throwable>
Parameters:
args - the arguments to the root ProcessorChainLink which serves as the input to the first Processor which produces the initial RESULT; these are passed along the chain for each and every link

Returns:
the result of the complete AbstractProcessorChain execution after being processed by onTerminate(Object, Object...)

Throws:
ChainExecutionException - if the AbstractProcessorChain halted due to an unrecoverable failure in one of its ProcessorChainLinks; this signals a chain-wide failure; failures of individual links may be handled in onInitiate(ProcessorChainLink, Object...) and onTraverse(Object, ProcessorChainLink, Object...)

Since:
1.3.0

onInitiate

protected abstract LINK_RESULT onInitiate(ProcessorChainLink<LINK_RESULT,LINK_FAILURE> root,
                                          Object... args)

This callback is invoked for the root ProcessorChainLink in this chain. It can be used to implement any pre-chain processing and should execute the root link which produces the first RESULT.

Parameters:
root - the first ProcessorChainLink which produces the initial RESULT

args - the arguments which are passed along to each successive ProcessorChainLink

Returns:
the RESULT which is produced by executing the first ProcessorChainLink

Since:
1.3.0

onTraverse

protected abstract LINK_RESULT onTraverse(LINK_RESULT result,
                                          ProcessorChainLink<LINK_RESULT,LINK_FAILURE> successor,
                                          Object... args)

This callback is invoked when the execution of the chain progresses from the current link to the next; i.e. a ProcessorChainLink successor is available. All implementations are expected to handle the process of crossing links by using the RESULT of the previous link's execution and invoking the successor as they see fit. The RESULT of the current link's execution should be returned so that it is passed along to the next successor.

Note that failures of recoverable Processors should be explicitly handled and recovered from where possible

As an example, consider a Processor with a result type of Void. This signifies that the Processor implementation does not return a result and its execution is based solely on the input to the processor chain. In such situations the RESULT should be ignored original argument array should be passed to the successor.

Consider another example where you require a premature termination of the chain for the current invocation context. An additional boolean flag could be added to a copy of the argument array which would be passed on to the successor. The implementation of onTraverse() and onTerminate should check the existence of this additional parameter and skip invocation of the successor and the terminal link respectively.

Although the Processor wrapped in the ProcessorChainLink may choose to skip the processing, this decision is limited to the input it receives and it's unaware of the implementation details of the chain in which it resides. Hence this decision can only be made from a context which has a holistic view of the AbstractProcessorChain.

Parameters:
result - the result from the execution of the current ProcessorChainLink which should be passed on to the successor link in this iteration of onTraverse()

successor - the next ProcessorChainLink which should be executed with the RESULT of the current link and the subsequent RESULT of this successor should be returned in turn

args - the arguments which are passed along to each successive ProcessorChainLink

Returns:
the RESULT which was produced by executing the successor ProcessorChainLink

Since:
1.3.0

onTerminate

protected abstract void onTerminate(LINK_RESULT result,
                                    Object... args)

This callback is invoked by the last link in the chain. It can be used for post-chain processing before allowing the chain to exit with the final RESULT.

Parameters:
result - the result from the execution of the final ProcessorChainLink

args - the arguments which were passed down from the preceding ProcessorChainLink

Since:
1.3.0
